posts.name: Hannah
posts.cooked:
We‚Äôre trying to connect a network switch to our radio so we can have multiple devices on our robot‚Äôs network. The radio is wired as following:

Other devices can‚Äôt be detected on the robot network if we connect them through the network switch, but they do work when being directly plugged into the rightmost port on the radio.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Have you checked the switch?  E.G. connect a laptop to it (using the same cable as you were with the radio) and see if you can detect those devices.

Also verify the switch is on the same subnet as your radio and other devices.
the way that we set up our switch, we connect the radio to the switch only and have it connected to the Rio through the switch, but it could differ depending on the type of switch you‚Äôre using.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Switches are generally layer 2 devices and wont have IP addresses of their own, so they won‚Äôt ‚Äúbe‚Äù on any subnet

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
The right port of the radio should not be used. It is on a separate controller from the left port/WiFi and it just loves to randomly not work right. Everything on the robot should go through one network switch connected to the left port.

For more info read this thread:

Why you probably shouldn't use the second port on your OpenMesh OM5P Radio and embrace using an Ethernet Switch instead Technical

link_counts.title: Why you probably shouldn't use the second port on your OpenMesh OM5P Radio and embrace using an Ethernet Switch instead

posts.name: Hannah
posts.cooked: We checked the network switch and turns out it was dead. Thank you!
